Trump ran on the promise that he would upend the Republican establishment's foreign policy.  He opposed free trade, neoconservative interventionism, and signing agreements providing no advantages to the US.  That means that there are no "old hands" that could aid him.  Cheney and Powell don't agree with his foreign policy ideas, nor do most of the establishment Republicans whom Trump disdains.

Just because you served in prior administrations, publish in Foreign Policy magazine, teach at an Ivy League international affairs department, or attained the rank of general doesn't mean that your views aren't nonsensical and ineffective.  Trump is hated mostly because he has no respect for meaningless credentials, the ultimate currency for influence in DC and on the pages of the NYT.
I believe the word you are looking for is lemmings ...

President Cheney's foreign policy was defined by getting the most money to defense contractors and big oil companies. At a huge cost in American solders' lives. Trump on the other hand, is guided by keeping his grandiose view of himself in the public, but often there is no discernable  basis.
Is it November yet?

Unsaid here is the fact that Trump's Iran decisions have not led to war, have been amazingly successful according to some strategists, and are at present not endangering anyone, while the Khamenei regime is being rejected by its own people. Donald Trump's huge sin, according to James Mann? Being Donald Trump. Career "deep statists" cannot abide the fact that he is not one of them but is following his own path, as the voters decided he should in 2016.

What is this writer trying to convince us off? That we were better off under the Cheney regime than the Trump regime? That the two evils functioned differently does not make either desirable. Evil has many faces.

This is a very valid description of the critical uniqueness of Trump and his minions. It is too kind to Cheney, who practiced villainy when he could. He was tremendously hampered by only being Vice President. For example, consider his promotion of the yellowcake forgeries. These were so transparent that an eleven year old of average intelligence with dial-up internet would by following instructions in a children's book on espionage I read in junior high have quickly revealed their falsehood. For example, of those Nigerian officials who supposedly signed the documents (all in the same handwriting) some were at the date of the documents dead and others had not yet taken office. When a former US ambassador to Niger was sent there to see if there was any truth at all in the forgeries, he returned to say there was not. So Cheney orchestrated people in diverse government agencies and in the Republican intelligentsia to get revenge. The ambassadors wife lead a major covert CIA team overseas. To get his revenge, Cheney exposed her and her entire team.

It may seem that the psychology of the so-called WEIRD populations [populations characterized as Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, and Democratic] develop us towards a more authoritarian governance. Exemplified by the Anglo-Saxon tribe dominated countries UK, and USA. The complexity of interaction between any action and the result of that action in the globally interdependent world is – I think – beyond where intelligent, old time political decisions could be made. We want to make “USA great again” and “develop UK full potential”. Show me a voter who say no! if someone tells us he can do things, we trust he know how to do it. I am in the point in my life where I can see the crook in any hero and vice versa, I enjoy the emergence of China. The WEIRD shoot those we do not like, with guns or $. “Chinese”: like or not is irrelevant, can we do some business? “the West” have allegedly a military presence, directly or by proxies, in more than 180 countries. I can imagine that “The Chinese” have business communities in at least as many. I wonder which approach will be the most appreciated in the world during the 21 century?

Trump is one of the primal creatures in an international swamp of money and corruption.
If he thinks it can benefit him, he will deal away anybody else's job, their democratic rights such as  due process, their votes, and the honor of our military.
In a New York minute 
People have to stop refusing to see the implications of what they are seeing in Trump. (And that includes N Y Times reporters who should be more skeptical)
You give the benefit of the doubt to a bad person and they will keep on doing bad things.

The booing at the 1996 Powell speech was a warning of what was to come.  Not a rude aberration, it was a step down the road to the nativist party of today.  With that perspective, the party of today is the inevitable outcome, rational in its own way: foreign policy is an afterthought, white citizenship is central.
He's definitely a Dick something.

It should be obvious by now that when the Republicans gave in to Trump's demands for loyalty uber alles, they abandoned a great deal more than their traditional approaches to foreign policy.  They have given up any pretense of respecting any American traditions of constitutional government that stand in the way of Trump's personal rule in domestic policy as well.  The Republican approach to the impeachment trial will showcase exactly what we can expect if Trump continues in office for another four years (and beyond?)

The 2004 reelection campaign orchestrated against John Kerry by George W. & Cheney was far from gentlemanly. Attack ads. Swift boat veterans. “Flip-flop, Flip-flop.” Lies about extraordinary renditioning, enhanced interrogation, WMD’s. Many, many lies.
If Trump isn’t forced from office before hand, the general election campaign that is coming our way this fall promises to make the 2004 race look like a Sunday school picnic.
If Donald Trump had any friends, he would likely be affectionately known to them as “The Prince of Lies.”
And, as the election grows closer, the Prince appears to be motivated by a very real concern that failing to win a second term will land him in jail in New York state. This reality(?) could drive our normally hysterical, deceitful, irrationally unbalanced president to new heights of lunacy. No holds barred.

Dick Cheney was no poster boy for Mental Health, but he is shrewd, intelligent, experienced and cagy. Sixty thousand mental health professionals have signed a petition stating that Trump is psychologically unfit for office and a danger to the nation. They recommend that the 25th Amendment Shuffle be danced asap.
What Don will likely be willing to do to stay in office can be summed up in one word — ANYTHING.
No executive action, too crazy. No lie, too ludicrous. No “national emergency”, too bizarre.
Hang onto your hats!

In this, Dick Cheney’s darkness couldn’t come close to matching the threat posed by Donald Trump’s scrambled cognitive processes.

Does it really matter how different Trump and Cheney are? Or whether there are any adults in the room? When the end result  is the same - blood and treasure needlessly and mindlessly spent - does it make a difference that one is steeped in the traditions of politics and the other in business? For that matter, did it change things to have a Democrat in the White House (and, briefly, a Democratic-controlled Congress) in between these two Republican administrations? The ugly fact us that we are still in the Middle East, still in the thrall of the Military -Industrial Complex, some fifty-nine years after President Eisenhower so forcefully spoke against this very thing.

"...a single man and his vagaries" ?  not at all.

We now have a diplomacy and foreign policy via Fox and, therefore, Murdoch.

King Donald the 1st of the USA

Donald Trump must be crowned as the first king of the United States of America. It seems that he has far more godly power than even the Catholic’s Pope when it comes to knowing what must be done to make his “the greatest nation in world history”. His earthly success will show that he knows what is right and what is wrong when it comes to many things including wars, protection of the American dollar including deficit financing, correcting the misbelief in global warming and even to demanding whatever is required from the US taxpayers. 

As King, Donald Trump can …

Visit my Facebook site for the rest of this article.
Partially correct...
No, Donald Trump is no Dick Cheney, For one thing, Trump wouldn't know how to load a shotgun without shooting himself in the foot.

Ultimately, every president for the past several decades has weakened the moral authority of our country, used neoconliberalism and extended executive privilege*, for which there had previously been .no. precedents, to make every American less safe in the world, and compromised our superpower status, way before the accelerated pace at which Trump is doing it.        
*(Yes, even Obama weakened our nation on several points, 26,000 bombs dropped by Obama, without consulting Congress, backing Wall Street instead of Main Street, healthcare that backed an industry that removes billions in profit from denying life-saving, doctor prescribed care, supporting pipelines we don’t need, not acting on climate change, a trade deal that made US workers race to the bottom ...) 
Had enough of neoliberals and corporatists that prop a rigged economy yet? Bernie 2020

While Cheney was driven by "hawkish unilateralism" he was also driven by greed and how he and his friends could make money off US incursions abroad.  This current administration is no different and has just amplified potential profit-making considerations into foreign policy.  Do you really thing Trump isn't thinking about golf courses and hotels every time he talks to his dictator "friends?"  Any other foreign policy considerations, like, I don't know, say, the safety and security of the United States, play second fiddle when Trump and family think money can be made.

Oh stop it.  It's ALWAYS about the President's approach, not about schools of thought.  People now only remember and credit/discredit what Jefferson, Lincoln, FDR, etc. did or abstained from.  the different "schools" supporting different approaches are now at most historical footnotes.
What we had in GWB was simply the worst disaster this country has ever known.  We have a fundamentally different geopolitical approach espoused in our current President's actions, and I welcome it.  It certainly in any event couldn't possibly approach the historical debacle that was Bush II.

Historical precedents or not, America's time of reckoning for the things being done in its name by Trump will surely come, and the longer he so freely gets away with doing unconscionable things according to his own rules, the tougher and more consequential that time reckoning will be on the American people and her once upon a time  closest allies.

James Mann's most chilling words in this column are: "There is no one to challenge Mr. Trump now."  We have a President who has 
"weaved, wavered and reversed course on foreign policy based on his views of the moment"--and the Republicans have followed.  In other words we do not have a patriotic American sitting in the Oval Office, and his party, as Mr. Mann states, has an "absence of ideas or strategy in the current policies on the Middle East and North Korea."

All Americans should be worried about where these inadequate buffoons are taking us, not only on foreign policy, but in a domestic policies that only benefit the President and some billionaires.  How did we fall so far in just three years?

Very informative. I too have been highly focused on the GOP as whole as opposed to Trump because I believe they are more responsible for the current problems within this administration. 
While President Trump is the one making the impulsive and inappropriate decisions, the GOP are enabling the President while undermining our constitution and American citizens. Their behavior resembles that of a cult and President Trump has repeatedly demonstrated he believes he is a king/dictator. I am baffled that such a simple minded individual could have such an impact on so many well educated individuals. I am starting to believe my husband's view that people are more inclined to act in their own best interest rather than doing the right thing.

At the risk of sounding alarmist, leaving the fate of nation and world to the vagaries of a man like Trump and his sycophants is the greatest threat America has ever faced in modern times. But I have never thought it was the Neo-conservative ideology or any other that gave us Trump: it was the alienation of working-class America from a Government that no longer represents them, as well as the deep racial divide that is being used by the extreme right to stoke the fears of “traditional America” and keep those who share the same economic hardships from politically uniting. In other words, Trump is more of a product of our racial and class divisions than he is of our foreign policy.

Fair enough, but Cheney shares with Trump the ignominious distinction of using American foreign policy to enrich himself personally.  

Cheney retained all his stock in Halliburton even as he supported a war in which Halliburton made billions.  

Trump retained all of his various shady businesses while courting monsters like Erdogan, Putin, and bin Salman with the aim of expanding his real estate business overseas.

Interesting article. I think we're where we are now because of Newt Gingrich; and this bears repeating because people forget to reference him and they shouldn't. If American history has villains, I place him up there with guys like John Wilkes Booth. He brought the end of compromise which is a foundational democratic principle. Abetted by their propaganda TV arm, the GOP feels no compunction to compromise on anything but naming a post office after someone. I believe that's where this became intractable.

They are both criminals and the very worst kind: Murderers, just as George W. Bush is. Just because they held extremely high political offices does not qualify them to be immune to harsh judgment. It does allow them to (almost) "Do as one pleases". They may not have received any "Justice"; however, I believe this to be a "fair assessment" of who they are as people.

When one writes, one has to make sense.  The following two sentences are nonsensical.

"Republican foreign policy was once defined by clashing world views. Now it’s defined only by loyalty to the president."

Two highhanded and cruel men, totally untrustworthy, committed to lining their pockets and without honor. Nothing will separate their deplorable names in recording the darkest moments in American history.

Reagan was protected from any consequences of the Iran Contra scandal, a series of events that, had they happened under President Obama, would have sent millions of angry, white "patriots" into the streets demanding the President be impeached and removed for his treasonous behavior.  No, Trump is certainly not Cheney, but he is the logical outcome of a party wedded to nothing but the lust for absolute power and the right to commit murder in the name of the State for over 40 years.

Cheney's was the next stop in our journey down the slippery slope from the previous one defined  by Clinton 's foreign policy including the personal calculus . Cheney lied and fixed the intelligence .Powell offered him the fig leaf of softness honesty and legitimacy  . The two gangs worked very well . Trump has cornered the two He has internalized the dishonesty and the feeble attempts to hide that  dishonesty  . Interesting slope we are barrelling down . What the next stop would be like?

Exactly.  It cannot be overemphasized that Donald Trump is NOT conservative, any more than liberal. Whim, defensiveness, pathological hatred toward president Obama, narcissism, insecurity, greed, racism, misogyny--they are what motivate him. Not ideas, not beliefs--whether valid or otherwise. 

That's why Bolton can become a most unlikely hero in the impeachment: because he, unlike Trump, has beliefs, although they are all wrong.

Advisers with beliefs and ideas have not and cannot last long with Trump, because, just as you say, they have no currency with him. Only loyalty matters. This is part of our frightening decline into authoritarianism.

To be a true Republican , a president must demonstrate the ability to control  oil flows from the Mideast.Bush Sr. , Cheney, and Reagan set the pattern.Trump is fumbling to follow in his infantile way with no idea what our goal really is. Cheney was  clear.
Trump  made it clear that he was not protecting Western access to oil when he allowed the Iranians to attack tankers in the Gulf and did not retaliate for Saudi bombing. Instead he wants to make attacks on Iran about terrorism (probably to satisfy Israel and his base).Cheney used the subterfuge of WMD to get control of  Iraq's  valuable oil fields.
Real Conservatives wanted Cheney/Bush to attack Tehran . Trump thinks he can satisfy that desire but has miscalculated badly. Not even Cheney was that  crazy.

Trump is no Dick Cheney, because he hadn’t got a degree in political science. He is what his voters want from him. They don’t care about his deafening unfitness to serve the countray, as long as he serves their purposes.  He Is different from other Republican presidents due to his extreme narcissism and opportunism. Going to great lengths to remain in power the GOP rallies behind him. 
Despite clashing with Trump over European allies in NATO  and Muslim ban etc, Cheney supports Trump’s bid for re-election and attened a fundraiser for Trump last August in Jackson, Wyoming.   
On March 27, 2017 during a speech at an economic forum in India, Cheney said that alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 election could be considered an "act of war," claiming  the Russian efforts were directed by  Putin. 
Nevertheless he and other Republicans still back their president. 
Neocons wouldn’t mind that Trump stumble into another endless war, because it might make them appear less guilty after the two disastrous wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Besides, it would boost the arms industry from which they could benefit.

We immerse ourselves in foreign affairs and neglect our domestic affairs. The media needs fast-breaking news from continual strife. Republican politicians need distraction of the  voters from domestic problems.

Ah, the thrashings and throes of a fading economic power with big bombs!

Mirror images of the abuse of power. 
One inside the GOP establishment and one outside it.

Mr. Mann's article made it appear that Dick Cheney was that statesman though more of an ideologue rather than. While he appeared more the elder brother of Pres G W Bush, he was a "planted" operative and both engineered the "invasion" of Iraq and poor Gen. Powell who was made the bigger fool. The fleecing by very few in the loop including Cheney's Halliburton of the military industrial complex was appalling. However symbolically only, the Iraqi parliament resolution to kick the US out tells us that the trillions spent and the lives lost were for "Nada, Zilch, Zero. What foreign policy, Mr. Mann?

I don't care about the differences. I care about my brother who was sent to Iraq in 2003, whose convoys were blown up time and again by various kinds of IEDs until one finally rattled him inside his vehicle so hard it took his hearing and injured his brain, and killed his friends. 

I care that his body and his friends were sacrificed for lies that were force fed to the American public as we were sick with fear after 9/11. I care about what he had to endure and what he had to do for those lies. 

And I know there are millions of Iraqis who feel the same way and worse because of what our country did to their families and their homes. 

I have no forgiveness in my heart for Dick Cheney and the rest of the Bush administration for what they sent other people's family to do. I don't really care for those who voted to authorize it. 

There should be a law that says if we are going to send troops to war, that the sons and daughters of those who voted for it have to serve in combat for that war. 

And if Trump brings us to war with Iran over more lies and situations he himself put into motion, I do not care about the distinctions between those actions and those of Cheney, Bush, Rumsfeld, Wolfowitz, Bolton, Powell, and the rest of them. 

The differences don't matter. The lies matter. Because the people matter. These people are the worst among us.

Hundreds of thousands of people we couldn't bother to count are still suffering from Cheney's crimes against humanity. Their lives were destroyed - families, homes, towns all blown apart. Children who lost limbs or were burned left to suffer every day with searing pain and no hope of improving. We even turned our backs on the people who helped us at great risk to themselves. 

Does Dick Cheney spend a moment even thinking of any of them? It's grotesque to think how many million American tax dollars have been spent on the medical care of this war criminal. Grotesque to think yet another reckless Republican has been able to hurt so many while living in comfort. 

We could do so much good in the world. But with sick men like these in power, destruction and suffering will reign.

The Republican party does not exist anymore, there is only the party of Trump and his boot lickers. All that remains is for Trump to imperially bequeath the hollow shell of what used to be the party of Abraham Lincoln to one of his misbegotten offspring, to make its downfall complete. Ivanka for 2024!
Do not get lost in nuance .America Empire is the driving idealogy. Trump has taken an Empire like attitude, sanctions and tariffs are his weapons.It will end the same way all Empires die.
Neither have blood coursing through their veins,  of that I am sure.   Both pathological, vindictive and without souls.
Apparently loyalty to this president is equivalent to loyalty to Russia.

I am a Navy Vietnam veteran ('65-'69) and a retired federal prosecuting attorney (1995-2010).
 
I would add that had it not been for the likes of W., Dick Cheney, Richard Perle, Paul Wolfowicz, Scooter Libby et al.(all of them chicken hawk draft dodgers) and Condoleeza Rice who  lied [to justify their Preventive War Doctrine"] to the American people about the phantom "WMD's" and caused hundreds of thousands of deaths and catastrophic destruction  and untold suffering, we would not be here today. 

Moreover,  I would argue that 45 is just following the Republican Foreign Policy ushered in by W, his predecessor in incompetence who, like 45,  was way over his head.
A failure at business, a president who is ashamed to allow his tax returns or academic records to be seen, a man who’s gone bankrupt five times — has philosophically bankrupted the Republican party.

Nothing in this administration is comparable to any previous American administration!  Trump makes Nixon look like a choir boy.

'... experienced advisers can sometimes deflect a president’s worst instincts and ideas.' 

Trump has systematically removed every obstacle to his narcissistic, false persona;  especially any intelligent individual  who might credibly challenge  him.  He is a weak, cowardly, dangerous man. If that was the plan Trump shot himself (us) in the foot.  With our murder of the second most important leader in Iran, the likelihood of any negotiations with Iran are now absolutely gone.

The deeper the holes this president digs himself into, the more loudly his republican enablers defend him. This is just so not right.

It's hardly surprising that the Times won't report on the mind boggling reality of Iranian students refusing to trample American and Israeli flags. Nor should one expect a retraction of last week's reporting of how the termination of Soleimani "united" the Iranian people. Clearly millions of Iranians and Iraqis were dancing in their homes to celebrate the death of that mass murderer. As for today's Times report  about the current anti-government demonstrations (which so fly in the face of last week's report on Iranian unity) the  Gray Lady will not even allow talkbacks. Such is the censorship at the Times. What we get instead is this piece of conjecture about how Trump is no Dick Cheney. We have just witnessed the decisive and long overdue action by Trump which has effectively defanged the Iranians, forced them to show their true colors -- as well as the craven colors of the American mainstream media -- and galvanized the American People. Yet the best the Times can come up with (rather than show the big news of Iranian solidarity with America and Israel, and perhaps offer an editorial apology) is a self-serving op-ed attempting to make a negative comparison between Trump and the once equally reviled Cheney. The US is responsible for millions of deaths around the world, from central and South America to the Middle East to South Asia and yet continue to masquerade as the shiniest object in the sky. 
The rest of the world is very clear on this, they are not confused. The only people in denial are Americans and America’s power and influence is on a steep downward slide. 
It’s not an overnight thing for sure, but let’s be clear America, it’s over!  It’s just a matter of time now.

 I can't even say Donald Trump is  worse; Trump is morally reprehensible- and stupid, while Cheney was/is morally reprehensible and intelligent. The person most resembling Cheney in the current administration is Stephen Miller; one whose very countenance makes me shudder.

Do none of you know how dangerous it is to have in power a man whose brain developed aberrantly, who does not, and never has, cared about anyone but himself?  Can’t you just look at Trump’s facial expressions, his archetypical psychopath smirk, to realize that something important is awry?

Trump scores at least 35 on the Hare Psychopath Test - an extreme psychopath, with irrational intentions extremely different from those you imagine from a fellow human being.

FDR ushered in a durable political era, lasting until the late 1970s, in which both major political parties were suspicious of extreme accumulations of wealth and power -- both political and economic power. The aversion to both types of power was informed by recent experience: The Great Depression, caused by overly concentrated economic power, and the rise of fascism, caused by overly concentrated political power. Moreover, Americans in this era felt, correctly, that these kinds of concentrated powers were linked with each other. This era ended in the late 1970s, and came to be replaced by what we could call the Reagan consensus -- in which both parties now agree that the extreme accumulation of economic power is not in itself a problem -- hence the era of deregulation that continues today -- but only disagree about how much to tax this wealth after it accumulates. Naturally, we are now seeing the specter of fascism rising again, in connection to the historic economic inequality this neoliberalism has created, but this time it's rising in our own country. Warren is the candidate who best understands this process, and is likeliest to finally end this Reagan era. https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/10/how-democrats-killed-their-populist-soul/504710/

What Roosevelt did certainly mitigated the effects of the great depression but it did not end it. WW2 ended the great depression. Until then, there just wasn't enough for everyone to do. 

According to US government statistics, during the height of the depression, unemployment ran around 20%. By 1940 it was down to about 14%, and in 1942 it dropped to 4.7%. It's likely that Roosevelt's projects made the 6% difference.

In other words, there was no systemic change. The improvement was palliative and temporary. It took mobilizing the nation to fight the war that created the structural improvement, and it has been the constant war footing that has kept it robust. Stop that and the depression will come back immediately.

By all means, fix our crumbling infrastructure, but don't fool yourself: the economy can't sustain itself without massive government spending and employment. And to sustain that, you need to either raise taxes or borrow.

You express the very common, perhaps general, view that FDR "rescued the country from the Great Depression".  This is not so.  The slump continued through the entire decade of the 1930s.  

The worst year was 1932, with an unemployment of 25%.  This is an incredible number.  Normal (nominal "full employment") is about 4%, so we had unemployment increase six fold. adding another 21% of unemployed persons.  

By comparison, The Great Recession of 2008-2011 saw unemployment reach only 10%.  From the normal 4%,  the recession added  only another 6% of unemployed persons.

The Great Depression remained far above the unemployment figures for our fairly recent slump.  After some amelioration, the unemployment rate rose upward to 19% in 1938.  And the average for the next three years, 1939-1941 was 17%, still much higher than the worst of the Great Recession.

Keynes taught us that under, and ONLY under, the condition of a complete investment slump (ie, no new factories, etc) the cure for unemployment is running a scandalously high deficit.

The problem is that Roosevelt's budget was nowhere near enough to heal the depression. 

It was cured by the far more effective  jobs and deficit program known as the Second World War.  

Total federal expenditure for the four (4) years of the war was about 5 times as large as it was during the previous nine (9) years of Roosevelt's administration.
